title: James L. Mitchell
text: James L. Mitchell (29 September 1834 in <a href="Shelby%20County%2C%20Kentucky">Shelby County, Kentucky</a> – 22 February 1894) was an American lawyer, army officer and 11th mayor of the city of <a href="Indianapolis%2C%20Indiana">Indianapolis, Indiana</a>. Mitchell was born in <a href="Kentucky">Kentucky</a> and settled in Indianapolis in 1859 where he <a href="Reading%20law">read law</a>. During the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>, Mitchell was an officer in the <a href="70th%20Regiment%20Indiana%20Infantry">70th Regiment Indiana Infantry</a> and, near the end of the war, a <a href="major">major</a> on the staff of General <a href="Lovell%20Rousseau">Lovell Rousseau</a>. He returned to his law practice following the war and in 1873 became the first <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democratic Party</a> mayor of Indianapolis since <a href="Charles%20G.%20Coulon">Charles G. Coulon</a> twenty-seven years earlier. In fact from 1856 to 1890, Mitchell's two-year term (1873–1875) is the only one not served by a <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a>.
